I think that your proof is fine. Regarding the missing inequality, you have already shown that 
$\frac{d\nu}{d\mu}\frac{d\mu}{d\nu}=1$ a.e., so of course you have 
$$
0<\frac{d\nu}{d\mu}\frac{d\mu}{d\nu}<\infty.
$$

###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
μ, ν, η are σ-finite measures,
μ is absolutely continuous with respect to ν (μ ≪ ν),
ν is absolutely continuous with respect to η (ν ≪ η).
Problem: 
Prove that $$\frac{d\mu}{d\eta} = \frac{d\mu}{d\nu} \cdot \frac{d\nu}{d\eta}$$ holds η-almost surely.

---

Assumption: 
μ and ν are finite measures,
μ is absolutely continuous with respect to ν (μ ≪ ν),
ν is absolutely continuous with respect to μ (ν ≪ μ).
Problem: 
Prove that  
$$0 < \frac{d\mu}{d\nu} \cdot \frac{d\nu}{d\mu} < \infty$$  
holds μ-almost surely (and therefore ν-almost surely), and  
$$\frac{d\mu}{d\nu} = \left( \frac{d\nu}{d\mu} \right)^{-1}$$  
holds μ-almost surely.
###END_OF_FORMAT###
